title: Harry Kane bemoans Tottenham’s lack of bravery in defeat at Liverpool
text:
Harry Kane opened the scoring against Liverpool at Anfield (Picture: Getty Images)

Harry Kane has admitted that Tottenham ‘could have been a bit braver’ in their 2-1 defeat to Liverpool in the Premier League on Sunday.

Spurs took the lead at Anfield through Kane in the first minute, but eventually fell to defeat after a Jordan Henderson equaliser and a Mohamed Salah penalty with 15 minutes to play.

Defeat continued Tottenham’s rocky start to the season, with four defeats in the Premier League already, leaving them in the bottom half of the table.

Kane admitted that the loss leaves his team disappointed, but surprisingly questioned his side’s bravery in the repeat of last season’s Champions League final.

‘Whenever you lose, you can never be encouraged. We battled but you expect that at this level in every game,’ said the England captain.

‘It’s disappointing being 1-0 up at half-time, being ahead and not being able to see it through.

Jordan Henderson and Mohamed Salah scored the goals for Liverpool on Sunday (Picture: Getty Images)

‘When you lose a game, it’s not a step forward — it showed we’ve got to work hard.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘It’s disappointing, so we’ll assess it and see where we can improve. Then, hopefully, we can take it into Everton on Sunday.

‘We could have been a bit braver. When we went 2-1 down, we started to do it better, create two or three chances towards the end but it was too late.’

Spurs boss Mauricio Pochettino called for calm and unity after the defeat on Merseyside, claiming that his team deserve a lot more than they have got this campaign so far.

‘After five and a half years it’s a moment to be all together and show our support,’ said Pochettino.

‘In this season we deserve more points on the table. It’s a moment to stay strong, to keep pushing.

‘Of course in a different season this game could have finished two or three nil for us. But today for us it is a different way and we must stay calm and take the best decisions for the future.’

The Champions League runners-up have a week off now, before returning to Premier League action at Everton on Sunday.
